contentMetadata.content:
{{Short description|Canadian video game developer}}
{{distinguish|text=the software developing community [[Phoenix Labs (software)]], formerly Methlabs}}
{{Infobox company
| name = Phoenix Labs
| logo = Phoenix Labs Logo.png
| type = [[Privately held company|Private]]
| industry = [[Video game industry|Video games]]
| founded = {{Start date and age|df=yes|2014|04}}
| hq_location_city = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]]
| hq_location_country = [[Canada]]
| num_locations = 4<ref>{{cite web |url=https://phxlabs.ca/ |title=Phoenix Labs |publisher=Phxlabs.ca |date= |access-date=2022-07-31 |archive-date=2022-07-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220731142607/https://phxlabs.ca/ |url-status=live }}</ref> (as of 2021)
| parent = [[Garena]] 2020-2023 

| subsid = Bot School Inc.
| website = {{URL|https://phxlabs.ca/}}
}}

'''Phoenix Labs''' is a Canadian [[video game developer]] based in [[Vancouver]], British Columbia. The company was founded in April 2014 by former [[Riot Games]] developers Jesse Houston, Sean Bender, and Robin Mayne.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|title=League of Legends vets form Phoenix Labs|url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2014-08-27-league-of-legends-vets-form-phoenix-labs|access-date=2021-08-22|website=GamesIndustry.biz|date=27 August 2014|language=en|archive-date=2021-08-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210822012246/https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2014-08-27-league-of-legends-vets-form-phoenix-labs|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2014-09-03-phoenix-labs-lessons-learned-from-league-of-legends|title=Phoenix Labs' lessons learned from League of Legends|website=GamesIndustry.biz|date=3 September 2014|language=en|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430213309/https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2014-09-03-phoenix-labs-lessons-learned-from-league-of-legends|url-status=live}}</ref> The studio's first project, [[Dauntless (video game)|''Dauntless'']], launched in open beta on Microsoft Windows in May 2018<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2018/05/25/dauntless-open-beta-launched/|title=Dauntless invites everyone to slay some poor animals in its open beta|last=Cox|first=Matt|date=2018-05-25|website=Rock, Paper, Shotgun|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-05-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190513221157/https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2018/05/25/dauntless-open-beta-launched/|url-status=live}}</ref> and has been released on [[PC game|PC]], [[PlayStation 4]], and [[Xbox One]] on May 21, 2019 and released on [[Nintendo Switch]] on December 10, 2019.

== History ==
Phoenix Labs was founded in 2014 by Jesse Houston, Sean Bender, and Robin Mayne, all former developers with Riot Games.<ref name=":0" /> The founders were joined by former [[BioWare|Bioware]], [[Riot Games]], [[Capcom]], and [[Blizzard Entertainment]] developers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gamerant.com/dauntless-reveal-game-awards/|title=Former BioWare, Riot, Capcom, Solstice, Blizzard Devs Announce 'Dauntless'|date=2016-12-01|website=Game Rant|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083128/https://gamerant.com/dauntless-reveal-game-awards/|url-status=live}}</ref> The first 23 of the studio's employees had all shipped games with Houston previously.<ref name=":2">{{cite web|url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2018-10-22-dauntless-labs-on-walking-the-line-between-dauntless-and-reckless|title=Phoenix Labs on walking the line between Dauntless and reckless|website=GamesIndustry.biz|date=22 October 2018|language=en|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430051254/https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2018-10-22-dauntless-labs-on-walking-the-line-between-dauntless-and-reckless|url-status=live}}</ref>

In February 2018, Phoenix Labs opened its first US studio in San Mateo, California <ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20180214006045/en/Phoenix-Labs-Raises-Series-B-Financing-from-Sapphire-Ventures-GGV-Ridge-Signia-Next-Frontier-and-MTGx|title = Phoenix Labs Raises Series B Financing from Sapphire Ventures, GGV, Ridge, Signia, Next Frontier and MTGX|date = 14 February 2018|access-date = 13 December 2021|archive-date = 13 December 2021|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20211213155254/https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20180214006045/en/Phoenix-Labs-Raises-Series-B-Financing-from-Sapphire-Ventures-GGV-Ridge-Signia-Next-Frontier-and-MTGx|url-status = live}}</ref>

In February 2018, Phoenix Labs received Series B funding from tech investors including [[Sapphire Ventures]], [[GGV Capital|GGV]], Next Frontier, and MTGx,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wccftech.com/dauntless-dev-raises-series-b-financing/|title=Dauntless Developer Raises Series B Financing Round To Build Upon The Game's Foundation|last=Palumbo|first=Alessio|date=2018-02-15|website=Wccftech|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083114/https://wccftech.com/dauntless-dev-raises-series-b-financing/|url-status=live}}</ref> though they maintained independent control of the studio.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2018-02-14-if-loot-boxes-are-free-to-plays-present-what-will-be-the-future|title=If loot boxes are free-to-play's present, what will be the future?|website=GamesIndustry.biz|date=14 February 2018|language=en|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430213316/https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2018-02-14-if-loot-boxes-are-free-to-plays-present-what-will-be-the-future|url-status=live}}</ref> Throughout ''Dauntless''' development and pre-release, the company encouraged back and forth conversations between developers and players.<ref name=":4">{{cite web|url=https://gamedaily.biz/article/690/phoenix-labs-jesse-houston-community-involvement-is-the-beating-heart-of-dauntless|title=Phoenix Labs' Jesse Houston: 'Community involvement' is the beating heart of Dauntless|website=GameDaily.biz|language=en|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083127/https://gamedaily.biz/article/690/phoenix-labs-jesse-houston-community-involvement-is-the-beating-heart-of-dauntless|url-status=live}}</ref> [[Game design]]ers, directors, and executives all connect with players regularly through forums and social media.<ref name=":3">{{cite web|date=2018-03-10|title=Dauntless: Making a different kind of monster hunting game|url=https://venturebeat.com/2018/03/10/dauntless-making-a-different-kind-of-monster-hunting-game/|access-date=2019-05-20|website=VentureBeat|language=en-US|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083124/https://venturebeat.com/2018/03/10/dauntless-making-a-different-kind-of-monster-hunting-game/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=":4" /> Since the game's beta release, the studio has continued to make changes based on player feedback and discussion.<ref name=":3" /> For example, ''Dauntless'' originally featured a paid [[loot box]]es system called "Chroma Cores," which were removed after they received negative feedback from players.<ref name=":3" />

In July 2018, Phoenix Labs announced that ''Dauntless'' had reached 2 million registered accounts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2018/07/17/phoenix-labs-dauntless-hits-2-million-players-and-readies-big-expansion/|title=Phoenix Labs' Dauntless hits 2 million players and readies big expansion|date=2018-07-17|website=VentureBeat|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430052038/https://venturebeat.com/2018/07/17/phoenix-labs-dauntless-hits-2-million-players-and-readies-big-expansion/|url-status=live}}</ref> The studio raised another round of funding in October 2018, led by [[Sapphire Ventures]],<ref name=":2" /> intended to help expand the [[Games as a service|live service]] operations of ''Dauntless''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://massivelyop.com/2018/10/23/dauntless-developer-phoenix-labs-leads-financing-round-to-secure-a-couple-years-of-runway/|title=Dauntless dev Phoenix Labs leads financing round to secure 'a couple years of runway' {{!}} Massively Overpowered|last=Daniel|first=Matt|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430051251/https://massivelyop.com/2018/10/23/dauntless-developer-phoenix-labs-leads-financing-round-to-secure-a-couple-years-of-runway/|url-status=live}}</ref> In December 2018 Phoenix Labs launched a [[Season pass (video games)|season pass]] feature called Hunt Pass, a series of challenges that promise limited-time rewards while the season lasts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pcgamer.com/dauntless-heading-to-epic-games-store-aiming-for-crossplay-across-all-platforms/|title=Dauntless heading to Epic Games store, aiming for crossplay across all platforms|last=Davenport|first=James|date=2018-12-07|website=PC Gamer|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083120/https://www.pcgamer.com/dauntless-heading-to-epic-games-store-aiming-for-crossplay-across-all-platforms/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/monster-hunter-like-dauntless-gets-new-hunt-pass-a/1100-6466453/|title=Monster Hunter-Like Dauntless Gets New Hunt Pass And Content Update|last=Ramée|first=Jordan|date=2019-04-26|website=GameSpot|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430085735/https://www.gamespot.com/articles/monster-hunter-like-dauntless-gets-new-hunt-pass-a/1100-6466453/|url-status=live}}</ref>

The studio had originally promised a PlayStation 4 and Xbox One launch for ''Dauntless'' in April 2019,<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-12-07-monster-hunter-like-dauntless-headed-to-consoles-and-mobile-next-year|title=Monster Hunter-like Dauntless headed to consoles and mobile next year|last=Phillips|first=Tom|date=2018-12-07|website=Eurogamer|language=en|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083130/https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-12-07-monster-hunter-like-dauntless-headed-to-consoles-and-mobile-next-year|url-status=live}}</ref> though this date was later pushed to summer 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2019/03/13/dauntless-ps4-release-date-delay/|title=Dauntless PS4 Release Date Delayed to Summer 2019|date=2019-03-13|website=PlayStation LifeStyle|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083129/https://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2019/03/13/dauntless-ps4-release-date-delay/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egmnow.com/articles/news/dauntless-console-and-epic-games-store-release-delayed/|title=Dauntless console and Epic Games Store release delayed|website=EGMNOW.com|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083137/http://www.egmnow.com/articles/news/dauntless-console-and-epic-games-store-release-delayed/|url-status=live}}</ref> The game officially launched on consoles on September 26, 2019.<ref>{{cite web|last=Olson|first=Mathew|date=2019-09-26|title=Dauntless Leaves Early Access With a New Weapon and a New Behemoth|url=https://www.usgamer.net/articles/dauntless-leaves-early-access-with-a-new-weapon-and-a-new-behemoth|access-date=2021-08-22|website=USgamer|language=en|archive-date=2019-09-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190927001549/https://www.usgamer.net/articles/dauntless-leaves-early-access-with-a-new-weapon-and-a-new-behemoth|url-status=dead}}</ref>

On January 29, 2020, [[Garena]] announced the acquisition of Phoenix Labs for an estimated US$150 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/business/companies-markets/garena-buys-gaming-developer-phoenix-labs-for-2037m|title=Garena buys gaming developer Phoenix Labs, sources say for over $203.7m|website=The Straits Times|access-date=2020-04-22|date=2020-01-29|archive-date=2020-04-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200417065957/https://www.straitstimes.com/business/companies-markets/garena-buys-gaming-developer-phoenix-labs-for-2037m|url-status=live}}</ref>

On December 2, 2020 Phoenix Labs announced it was opening two new offices in Los Angeles, California and Montreal, Quebec.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://phxlabs.ca/news/multi-studio-strategy/|title=New Games and Beyond: A Multi-Studio Future for Phoenix Labs|website=Phoenix Labs|access-date=2020-12-02|date=2020-12-02|archive-date=2020-12-02|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201202172108/https://phxlabs.ca/news/multi-studio-strategy/|url-status=dead}}</ref>

In February, 2023, Phoenix Labs re-gained their independence.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Dealess |first=Marie |last2=Editor |first2=ri Deputy |date=2023-02-03 |title=Phoenix Labs regains independence after management buyout |url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/phoenix-labs-regains-independence-after-management-buyout |access-date=2023-05-04 |website=GamesIndustry.biz |language=en |archive-date=2023-05-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230504083908/https://www.gamesindustry.biz/phoenix-labs-regains-independence-after-management-buyout |url-status=live }}</ref>

== Games developed ==

== Epic Games store criticism ==
In January 2019, Phoenix Labs announced partnership with [[Epic Games]] which made ''Dauntless'' available on PC exclusively through the Epic Games store and required all players to sign in using an Epic Games account.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brown|first=Fraser|date=2019-01-31|title=Dauntless is joining the Epic Games Store|url=https://www.pcgamer.com/all-dauntless-accounts-will-be-converted-into-epic-games-store-accounts-soon/|access-date=2019-05-20|website=PC Gamer|language=en-US|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083119/https://www.pcgamer.com/all-dauntless-accounts-will-be-converted-into-epic-games-store-accounts-soon/|url-status=live}}</ref>

While the move to make ''Dauntless'' an Epic Games store exclusive received criticism, Mayne cited cross-platform play as the partnership's main benefit.<ref>{{cite web|date=2019-04-01|title=Dauntless exclusivity on Epic Games Store is for cross-play|url=https://www.tweaktown.com/news/65414/dauntless-exclusivity-epic-games-store-cross-play/index.html|access-date=2019-05-20|website=www.tweaktown.com|language=en|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083128/https://www.tweaktown.com/news/65414/dauntless-exclusivity-epic-games-store-cross-play/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

contentMetadata.text: Phoenix Labs is a Canadian video game developer based in Vancouver, British Columbia. The company was founded in April 2014 by former Riot Games developers Jesse Houston, Sean Bender, and Robin Mayne. The studio's first project, Dauntless, launched in open beta on Microsoft Windows in May 2018 and has been released on PC, PlayStation 4, and Xbox One on May 21, 2019 and released on Nintendo Switch on December 10, 2019. Phoenix Labs was founded in 2014 by Jesse Houston, Sean Bender, and Robin Mayne, all former developers with Riot Games. The founders were joined by former Bioware, Riot Games, Capcom, and Blizzard Entertainment developers. The first 23 of the studio's employees had all shipped games with Houston previously. In February 2018, Phoenix Labs opened its first US studio in San Mateo, California In February 2018, Phoenix Labs received Series B funding from tech investors including Sapphire Ventures, GGV, Next Frontier, and MTGx, though they maintained independent control of the studio. Throughout Dauntless' development and pre-release, the company encouraged back and forth conversations between developers and players. Game designers, directors, and executives all connect with players regularly through forums and social media. Since the game's beta release, the studio has continued to make changes based on player feedback and discussion. For example, Dauntless originally featured a paid loot boxes system called "Chroma Cores," which were removed after they received negative feedback from players. In July 2018, Phoenix Labs announced that Dauntless had reached 2 million registered accounts. The studio raised another round of funding in October 2018, led by Sapphire Ventures, intended to help expand the live service operations of Dauntless. In December 2018 Phoenix Labs launched a season pass feature called Hunt Pass, a series of challenges that promise limited-time rewards while the season lasts. The studio had originally promised a PlayStation 4 and Xbox One launch for Dauntless in April 2019, though this date was later pushed to summer 2019. The game officially launched on consoles on September 26, 2019. On January 29, 2020, Garena announced the acquisition of Phoenix Labs for an estimated US$150 million. On December 2, 2020 Phoenix Labs announced it was opening two new offices in Los Angeles, California and Montreal, Quebec. In February, 2023, Phoenix Labs re-gained their independence. In January 2019, Phoenix Labs announced partnership with Epic Games which made Dauntless available on PC exclusively through the Epic Games store and required all players to sign in using an Epic Games account. While the move to make Dauntless an Epic Games store exclusive received criticism, Mayne cited cross-platform play as the partnership's main benefit. "Phoenix Labs". Phxlabs.ca. texts.title: History
texts.value:
Phoenix Labs was founded in 2014 by Jesse Houston, Sean Bender, and Robin Mayne, all former developers with Riot Games.<ref name=":0" /> The founders were joined by former [[BioWare|Bioware]], [[Riot Games]], [[Capcom]], and [[Blizzard Entertainment]] developers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gamerant.com/dauntless-reveal-game-awards/|title=Former BioWare, Riot, Capcom, Solstice, Blizzard Devs Announce 'Dauntless'|date=2016-12-01|website=Game Rant|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083128/https://gamerant.com/dauntless-reveal-game-awards/|url-status=live}}</ref> The first 23 of the studio's employees had all shipped games with Houston previously.<ref name=":2">{{cite web|url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2018-10-22-dauntless-labs-on-walking-the-line-between-dauntless-and-reckless|title=Phoenix Labs on walking the line between Dauntless and reckless|website=GamesIndustry.biz|date=22 October 2018|language=en|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430051254/https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2018-10-22-dauntless-labs-on-walking-the-line-between-dauntless-and-reckless|url-status=live}}</ref>

In February 2018, Phoenix Labs opened its first US studio in San Mateo, California <ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20180214006045/en/Phoenix-Labs-Raises-Series-B-Financing-from-Sapphire-Ventures-GGV-Ridge-Signia-Next-Frontier-and-MTGx|title = Phoenix Labs Raises Series B Financing from Sapphire Ventures, GGV, Ridge, Signia, Next Frontier and MTGX|date = 14 February 2018|access-date = 13 December 2021|archive-date = 13 December 2021|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20211213155254/https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20180214006045/en/Phoenix-Labs-Raises-Series-B-Financing-from-Sapphire-Ventures-GGV-Ridge-Signia-Next-Frontier-and-MTGx|url-status = live}}</ref>

In February 2018, Phoenix Labs received Series B funding from tech investors including [[Sapphire Ventures]], [[GGV Capital|GGV]], Next Frontier, and MTGx,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wccftech.com/dauntless-dev-raises-series-b-financing/|title=Dauntless Developer Raises Series B Financing Round To Build Upon The Game's Foundation|last=Palumbo|first=Alessio|date=2018-02-15|website=Wccftech|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083114/https://wccftech.com/dauntless-dev-raises-series-b-financing/|url-status=live}}</ref> though they maintained independent control of the studio.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2018-02-14-if-loot-boxes-are-free-to-plays-present-what-will-be-the-future|title=If loot boxes are free-to-play's present, what will be the future?|website=GamesIndustry.biz|date=14 February 2018|language=en|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430213316/https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2018-02-14-if-loot-boxes-are-free-to-plays-present-what-will-be-the-future|url-status=live}}</ref> Throughout Dauntless' development and pre-release, the company encouraged back and forth conversations between developers and players.<ref name=":4">{{cite web|url=https://gamedaily.biz/article/690/phoenix-labs-jesse-houston-community-involvement-is-the-beating-heart-of-dauntless|title=Phoenix Labs' Jesse Houston: 'Community involvement' is the beating heart of Dauntless|website=GameDaily.biz|language=en|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083127/https://gamedaily.biz/article/690/phoenix-labs-jesse-houston-community-involvement-is-the-beating-heart-of-dauntless|url-status=live}}</ref> [[Game design]]ers, directors, and executives all connect with players regularly through forums and social media.<ref name=":3">{{cite web|date=2018-03-10|title=Dauntless: Making a different kind of monster hunting game|url=https://venturebeat.com/2018/03/10/dauntless-making-a-different-kind-of-monster-hunting-game/|access-date=2019-05-20|website=VentureBeat|language=en-US|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083124/https://venturebeat.com/2018/03/10/dauntless-making-a-different-kind-of-monster-hunting-game/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=":4" /> Since the game's beta release, the studio has continued to make changes based on player feedback and discussion.<ref name=":3" /> For example, Dauntless originally featured a paid [[loot box]]es system called "Chroma Cores," which were removed after they received negative feedback from players.<ref name=":3" />

In July 2018, Phoenix Labs announced that Dauntless had reached 2 million registered accounts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2018/07/17/phoenix-labs-dauntless-hits-2-million-players-and-readies-big-expansion/|title=Phoenix Labs' Dauntless hits 2 million players and readies big expansion|date=2018-07-17|website=VentureBeat|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430052038/https://venturebeat.com/2018/07/17/phoenix-labs-dauntless-hits-2-million-players-and-readies-big-expansion/|url-status=live}}</ref> The studio raised another round of funding in October 2018, led by [[Sapphire Ventures]],<ref name=":2" /> intended to help expand the [[Games as a service|live service]] operations of Dauntless.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://massivelyop.com/2018/10/23/dauntless-developer-phoenix-labs-leads-financing-round-to-secure-a-couple-years-of-runway/|title=Dauntless dev Phoenix Labs leads financing round to secure 'a couple years of runway' {{!}} Massively Overpowered|last=Daniel|first=Matt|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430051251/https://massivelyop.com/2018/10/23/dauntless-developer-phoenix-labs-leads-financing-round-to-secure-a-couple-years-of-runway/|url-status=live}}</ref> In December 2018 Phoenix Labs launched a [[Season pass (video games)|season pass]] feature called Hunt Pass, a series of challenges that promise limited-time rewards while the season lasts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pcgamer.com/dauntless-heading-to-epic-games-store-aiming-for-crossplay-across-all-platforms/|title=Dauntless heading to Epic Games store, aiming for crossplay across all platforms|last=Davenport|first=James|date=2018-12-07|website=PC Gamer|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083120/https://www.pcgamer.com/dauntless-heading-to-epic-games-store-aiming-for-crossplay-across-all-platforms/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/monster-hunter-like-dauntless-gets-new-hunt-pass-a/1100-6466453/|title=Monster Hunter-Like Dauntless Gets New Hunt Pass And Content Update|last=Ramée|first=Jordan|date=2019-04-26|website=GameSpot|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430085735/https://www.gamespot.com/articles/monster-hunter-like-dauntless-gets-new-hunt-pass-a/1100-6466453/|url-status=live}}</ref>

The studio had originally promised a PlayStation 4 and Xbox One launch for Dauntless in April 2019,<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-12-07-monster-hunter-like-dauntless-headed-to-consoles-and-mobile-next-year|title=Monster Hunter-like Dauntless headed to consoles and mobile next year|last=Phillips|first=Tom|date=2018-12-07|website=Eurogamer|language=en|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083130/https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-12-07-monster-hunter-like-dauntless-headed-to-consoles-and-mobile-next-year|url-status=live}}</ref> though this date was later pushed to summer 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2019/03/13/dauntless-ps4-release-date-delay/|title=Dauntless PS4 Release Date Delayed to Summer 2019|date=2019-03-13|website=PlayStation LifeStyle|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083129/https://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2019/03/13/dauntless-ps4-release-date-delay/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egmnow.com/articles/news/dauntless-console-and-epic-games-store-release-delayed/|title=Dauntless console and Epic Games Store release delayed|website=EGMNOW.com|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-20|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083137/http://www.egmnow.com/articles/news/dauntless-console-and-epic-games-store-release-delayed/|url-status=live}}</ref> The game officially launched on consoles on September 26, 2019.<ref>{{cite web|last=Olson|first=Mathew|date=2019-09-26|title=Dauntless Leaves Early Access With a New Weapon and a New Behemoth|url=https://www.usgamer.net/articles/dauntless-leaves-early-access-with-a-new-weapon-and-a-new-behemoth|access-date=2021-08-22|website=USgamer|language=en|archive-date=2019-09-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190927001549/https://www.usgamer.net/articles/dauntless-leaves-early-access-with-a-new-weapon-and-a-new-behemoth|url-status=dead}}</ref>

On January 29, 2020, [[Garena]] announced the acquisition of Phoenix Labs for an estimated US$150 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/business/companies-markets/garena-buys-gaming-developer-phoenix-labs-for-2037m|title=Garena buys gaming developer Phoenix Labs, sources say for over $203.7m|website=The Straits Times|access-date=2020-04-22|date=2020-01-29|archive-date=2020-04-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200417065957/https://www.straitstimes.com/business/companies-markets/garena-buys-gaming-developer-phoenix-labs-for-2037m|url-status=live}}</ref>

On December 2, 2020 Phoenix Labs announced it was opening two new offices in Los Angeles, California and Montreal, Quebec.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://phxlabs.ca/news/multi-studio-strategy/|title=New Games and Beyond: A Multi-Studio Future for Phoenix Labs|website=Phoenix Labs|access-date=2020-12-02|date=2020-12-02|archive-date=2020-12-02|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201202172108/https://phxlabs.ca/news/multi-studio-strategy/|url-status=dead}}</ref>

In February, 2023, Phoenix Labs re-gained their independence.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Dealess |first=Marie |last2=Editor |first2=ri Deputy |date=2023-02-03 |title=Phoenix Labs regains independence after management buyout |url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/phoenix-labs-regains-independence-after-management-buyout |access-date=2023-05-04 |website=GamesIndustry.biz |language=en |archive-date=2023-05-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230504083908/https://www.gamesindustry.biz/phoenix-labs-regains-independence-after-management-buyout |url-status=live }}</ref>

texts.title: Epic Games store criticism
texts.value:
In January 2019, Phoenix Labs announced partnership with [[Epic Games]] which made Dauntless available on PC exclusively through the Epic Games store and required all players to sign in using an Epic Games account.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brown|first=Fraser|date=2019-01-31|title=Dauntless is joining the Epic Games Store|url=https://www.pcgamer.com/all-dauntless-accounts-will-be-converted-into-epic-games-store-accounts-soon/|access-date=2019-05-20|website=PC Gamer|language=en-US|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083119/https://www.pcgamer.com/all-dauntless-accounts-will-be-converted-into-epic-games-store-accounts-soon/|url-status=live}}</ref>

While the move to make Dauntless an Epic Games store exclusive received criticism, Mayne cited cross-platform play as the partnership's main benefit.<ref>{{cite web|date=2019-04-01|title=Dauntless exclusivity on Epic Games Store is for cross-play|url=https://www.tweaktown.com/news/65414/dauntless-exclusivity-epic-games-store-cross-play/index.html|access-date=2019-05-20|website=www.tweaktown.com|language=en|archive-date=2019-04-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190430083128/https://www.tweaktown.com/news/65414/dauntless-exclusivity-epic-games-store-cross-play/index.html|url-status=live}}</ref>
